Scientists are human beings that make mistakes, sometimes lie, often disagree with one another and sometimes have motivations other than seeking knowledge. You can‚Äôt believe everything you hear just because someone claiming to be a scientist says so. Didn‚Äôt you know that?

Instead of you arrogantly telling me what I know and what I don't know, let me give a glimpse of fact.
Science is a process of studying the natural world. It involves testing hypotheses with empirical data, and retesting the hypotheses until they are either rejected or become theory. That is the process that scientists use. Yes, scientists are human and can make mistakes, which is why it is a self-correcting process. 

Those who criticize scientific findings, including well-established theories such as gravity and biological evolution, are also human but are rarely self-correcting. They tend to go by beliefs, while science is not a belief system.

You have demonstrated that your belief system overrides the objectivity of the scientific process, which is why Frank was correct. For example, I've seen you write about "evidence" for a global flood. There is no such evidence. None, at least not in historic times. What you have done is taken an ancient parable, which is clearly written as a parable, and treated it as history. You then take your belief and shoehorn into the guise of science. That doesn't work.

The Grand Canyon was created when waters from the global flood drained off the continent very quickly when a dam holding back the inland sea eroded. There‚Äôs your evidence. The Grand Canyon is there. You can‚Äôt say it isn‚Äôt there. You and I have exactly the same evidence. If you choose to interpret that evidence differently, that‚Äôs your business, not mine. 

(You should look up the word ‚Äúsedimentary‚Äù in a dictionary.) (Wow. The more you talk the more I recognize how poor your English vocabulary is. You just don‚Äôt know what many words mean. Are you a high school graduate?)

How curious. I never used the word 'sedimentary' in the above post and I'm pretty sure I've never used it in any post I've ever made here. So, for you benefit, I'll use it in its proper context below.
Let's pretend, and it is just make-believe, that your story of the Grand Canyon formation is true. That leads to some interesting questions. 1) Why is the canyon so meandering? Certainly a torrent of that magnitude would go straight through the rocks below. 2) Although there are many impressive canyons in the world, shouldn't there be more around the globe to drain such a massive flood? 3) There are thousands upon thousands of sedimentary layers making up the walls of the canyon, including shale layers, limestones, sandstones, topped by more limestone and sandstone layers. How did all those layers get there in the mere 1636 years before the Noachian flood? 
Please use the scientific method to postulate your hypotheses to answer these questions.
The sedimentary layers through which the Grand Canyon was cut were laid down in a  single event ‚Ä¶ the global flood. It was a big flood.
